The values of the test statistic generated under the null hypothesis.
Monte Carlo test that a sample is drawn from a given distribution.

Suppose we wish to test whether a small sample has been drawn from a normal distribution. We decide that we will use the skew of the sample as a test statistic, and we will consider a p-value of 0.05 to be statistically significant.
After collecting our data, we calculate the observed value of the test statistic.

To determine the probability of observing such an extreme value of the skewness by chance if the sample were drawn from the normal distribution, we can perform a Monte Carlo hypothesis test. The test will draw many samples at random from their normal distribution, calculate the skewness of each sample, and compare our original skewness against this distribution to determine an approximate p-value.

link.data: # because our statistic is vectorized, we pass `vectorized=True`

data.value: The probability of obtaining a test statistic less than or equal to the observed value under the null hypothesis is ~70%. This is greater than our chosen threshold of 5%, so we cannot consider this to be significant evidence against the null hypothesis.
Note that this p-value essentially matches that of
, which relies on an asymptotic distribution of a test statistic based on the sample skewness.
This asymptotic approximation is not valid for small sample sizes, but
can be used with samples of any size.

link.data: # stats.skewtest(x) would produce an error due to small sample

data.value: The Monte Carlo distribution of the test statistic is provided for further investigation.

link.data: Monte Carlo distribution of test statistic
